title: What is a refugee? And how have refugees been impacted since President Trump took office?
section: Please provide the text you would like me to analyze.

title: Humanoid robots compete in China soccer tournament
description:
Four teams of robots competed in a 3-on-3 soccer tournament in China over the weekend. Organizers said that the humanoid robots operated independently and were powered by AI. The winner was Tsing-Hua University, which defeated China Agricultural University, 5-3.

The founder and CEO of Booster Robotics, the company that supplied the robot players, told the Associated Press that sports competitions offer the ideal testing ground for humanoid robots, helping to accelerate the development of both algorithms and integrated hardware-software systems.

description:
The latest production of the musical Evita — about Eva Perón, Argentina's first lady in the 1940s and early 1950s — is playing at London's Palladium theater through early September. But it's what the star does offstage that's creating lots of buzz.

title: Trump's tariffs raising the price of wedding dresses in the U.S.
description:
Wedding gown makers and sellers are urging the federal government to exempt formalwear from President Trump's sweeping new global tariffs — China is by far the biggest hub for bridal gowns — and not just dresses, but also trims and crystals, veils and hair pieces.

Many brands have already started raising prices to offset tariff costs. Some stores are still absorbing them; others have begun charging brides.

The bridal retailers association says tariffs will not bring gown-making jobs to the U-S given the highly limited pool of skilled craftsmen for hand-beading, embroidery or lacework.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.

title: This is the only prototype of the MingKwai typewriter
description:
The genius of this rare prototype MingKwai typewriter comes from the way Lin Yutang, its creator, decided to break down Chinese pictographs by their shapes, not by sounds.

title: How pride has evolved and stayed the same
description:
In 1994, New York's Pride festivities focused on human rights violations affecting gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender communities around the world. NPR's Jim Zarroli was there in 1994 and interviewed one of the original participants in the Stonewall riots.

Today, NPR's Korva Coleman explores how Pride may have evolved over the years but in many ways the goals of the LGBTQ community have remained the same.

title: Hegseth announces new name for USNS Harvey Milk
description:
The Pentagon has announced that the U.S. Navy is changing the name of one of its ships.

The USNS Harvey Milk will be renamed the Oscar V. Peterson. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth says the decision was made to take the politics out of ship naming.

Oscar V. Peterson was awarded the medal of honor for heroism during the Battle of the Coral Sea in 1942.

The USNS Harvey Milk was originally named in honor of Harvey Milk, a pioneering gay rights activist and Navy veteran.

title: Immigration detentions reach new record highs
description:
The number of people detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement has been rapidly growing.

More than 55,000 people are now held in ICE custody, according to data from the administration, numbers that now surpassed the administration's previous high of those detained, which was reached during Trump's first term in 2019.

Historical data collected by The Marshall Project suggest that the number — met just this month — is the highest ever recorded. What’s more, it is nearly 15,000 more people than what ICE is currently funded for.

Immigration experts say a big driver of the growth in how many people are detained comes from a shift in priorities: The Trump administration is arresting more people who haven’t committed any crimes beyond their civil immigration violation. Nearly three out of four people currently in ICE custody have no criminal record — and that includes minor offenses like traffic violations.

------------------------------------------------------

title: Anna Wintour to step down as Vogue Editor-in-Chief
description:
Long-time American “Vogue” editor-in-chief Anna Wintour has announced that she’s moving away from her position, but she’ll continue in her roles at Condé Nast and for “Vogue.”

Wintour’s plate has been full in recent years. In addition to the day-to-day editing of American “Vogue,” she oversees almost all of Conde Nast’s other brands including “Wired,” “Vanity Fair” and “GQ.”

Wintour joined “Vogue” as editor-in-chief in 1988. She went on to launch “Teen Vogue” and “Men’s Vogue.”

title: Sen. Lisa Murkowski says that if you want change, you cannot stay silent
description:
Sen. Lisa Murkowski, a moderate Republican from Alaska, tells NPR that if you want change, you cannot stay silent.

"Don't assume that anybody else is going to speak up for you," she told All Things Considered host Juana Summers. "It's when you stop speaking up that those of us who are in a position to listen start to think that, well, maybe maybe your silence means you think everything is OK."

title: Catie Cuan is teaching robots to move more gracefully through choreography
description: As the reality of domestic robots become less of an "if" and more of a "when", Catie Cuan says teaching machines to move more gracefully can help us feel more comfortable around them. Cuan is an artist, engineer and award-winning robot choreographer whose work explores the beauty, magic and unintended consequences of giving AI a robot body. She is teaching robots like NEO, created by Norwegian engineer Bernt Børnich, to move more gracefully through choreography.

title: Paris' iconic opera house celebrates 150 years
description: The famous Paris opera house known as the Opera Garnier is celebrating its 150th anniversary this year. Emperor Napoleon III commissioned the building in the 1850s but would never see its completion. Charles Garnier, the architect, wanted to create a building that was about celebrating the citizens of Paris -- not those born into wealth, but people who strived to succeed in society.

title: Zohran Mamdani set to win the Democratic primary for New York City mayor, toppling Cuomo
description:
New York state assemblyman Zohran Mamdani, a 33-year-old democratic socialist, is set to win Tuesday's Democratic primary for New York City mayor with about 44% of the vote, toppling former Gov. Andrew Cuomo and nine other candidates.

The most left-leaning candidate in a crowded field, Mamdani campaigned on raising taxes on the city’s billionaires to fund initiatives like free MTA buses and expanding mental health outreach teams as his rivals pledged to hire more police officers.

Mamdani came in well ahead of Cuomo, who has already conceded defeat in the race. Incumbent Mayor Eric Adams is running as an independent in November's general election, and Cuomo could still run as a third-party candidate.

title: Sen. Murkowski on Trump, the "threat of a tweet" and the duty to speak up | All Things Considered
description:
Sen. Lisa Murkowski, a moderate Republican from Alaska, has a reputation for bucking her party.

She sometimes broke away from President Trump on key issues during his first term like the push to repeal the Affordable Care Act and the confirmation of Justice Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. She detailed some of those moments in her new book, "Far From Home: An Alaskan Senator Faces the Extreme Climate of Washington, D.C."

Murkowski sat down with All Things Considered host Juana Summers to discuss her memoir, her thoughts on Trump's sweeping domestic policy bill and the future of democracy.

CHAPTERS
0:00 - On the “big, beautiful bill”
2:16 - On the bill to rescind funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and foreign aid
4:32 - On what she learned from her father’s time in politics
7:11 - On being willing to push back on the Trump administration
9:20 - On why so few Republicans willing to disagree with Trump
10:49 - On what she meant by “we are all afraid”
15:15 - On whether there’s room for moderates in the Republican party
17:35 - On whether it’s Congress’ role to shore up faith in democratic institutions
19:43 - On whether – given changes to abortion access – she regrets her support for Supreme Court justices
23:07 - “Do you think that the country's democracy is on unstable footing?”
25:05 - On concerns that voters and officials doubt election outcomes
28:16 - Her message to Americans who don’t feel they have a political home

CREDITS
Host: Juana Summers
Producer: Tyler Bartlam
Video Director: Mito Habe-Evans
Video Editor: Keren Carrion
Videographers: Nickolai Hammar, Keren Carrion
Audio Engineers: Cena Loffredo, Jay Czys

title: Trump: Israel, Iran 'don't know what the f*** they're doing'
description:
Expressing frustration with apparent violations of a ceasefire between Israel and Iran overnight, President Trump lashed out at both countries Tuesday morning, saying he wasn't happy with either of them and using an expletive U.S. presidents simply do not say on camera: "They don’t know what the f*** they’re doing."

The comment came hours after Israel and Iran agreed to stop their war, followed by accusations from Israel that Iran had broken the ceasefire. Trump told reporters outside the White House Tuesday, "I think they both violated it."

A short time later, from Air Force One, he posted on Truth Social that Israel would not attack Iran and that “Nobody will be hurt, the Ceasefire is in effect!”

title: Sen. Lisa Murkowski spoke to NPR hours before Iran retaliated against the United States on Monday
description:
Sen. Lisa Murkowski, a Republican from Alaska, spoke to NPR hours before Iran retaliated against the United States on Monday. Murkowski said she is “concerned” about Iran's response, but said there's important context to keep in mind regarding Tehran's nuclear program.

“Iran has been threatening with their continued efforts towards their own nuclear capabilities for far too long,” Murkowski told All Things Considered host Juana Summers.

title: Mahmoud Khalil speaks to NPR after ICE release
description:
Columbia University graduate student Mahmoud Khalil is now free on bail. He spent more than three months in detention. Khalil was detained, as the first of several students who had peacefully protested against the war in Gaza.

The Department of Homeland Security says Khalil’s detention was legal. Khalil is a legal, permanent resident of the United States.

title: Pentagon says Iranian nuclear capabilities 'devastated' after U.S. strikes
description:
"The order we received from our commander in chief was focused, it was powerful, and it was clear," Hegseth said Sunday morning at a press conference at the Pentagon. "We devastated the Iranian nuclear program. But it's worth noting the operation did not target Iranian troops or the Iranian people."

The U.S. attack on Iran's nuclear sites involved seven B-2 Stealth Bombers and also included at least one submarine, according to Gen. Dan Caine, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the Pentagon press conference.
Caine said the mission, dubbed "Operation Midnight Hammer," represented the largest B-2 strike in U.S. history, involving more than 125 aircraft — including decoy flights — and saw 75 precision guided weapons dropped on the sites. "Final battle damage will take some time, but initial battle damage assessments indicate that all three sites sustained extremely severe damage and destruction," Caine said.

Very few people knew details of the mission, Caine said, which began midnight Friday with B-2 bombers leaving from Kansas City, Mo.. Some of the bombers flew west into the Pacific as a decoy, while the main set of bombers flew 18 hours into Iran to carry out the attack."Once over land, the B-2s linked up with escort and support aircraft in a complex, tightly timed maneuver requiring exact synchronization across multiple platforms in a narrow piece of airspace, all done with minimal communications," Caine said.

Around 5 p.m. Eastern time Saturday, a submarine launched more than two dozen Tomahawk missiles at a nuclear site in Isfahan as the bombers entered Iranian airspace. From approximately 6:40 p.m. to 7:05 p.m. Eastern time, the B-2s dropped 14 bunker-buster bombs on multiple targets at the Fordo and Natanz nuclear sites.The planes did not come under fire before, during or after the attack, Caine said.

title: Jimmy Awards bring high-school Broadway hopefuls to NYC
description:
110 high schoolers from across the country descended on Times Square last week for their first taste of fame. The National High School Musical Theatre Awards, better known as the Jimmy Awards, bring some of Broadway’s rising stars to New York City each year to put on a show unlike any other– in just 10 days. The competition starts with about 150,000 kids from schools across the nation. After regional competitions, a select few make it to New York City to perform in the awards show at the Minskoff Theatre. The top two awards of the night – best actor and best actress in a musical – are named after Broadway legend Jimmy Nederlander.

------------------------------------------------------

title: Trump administration cuts specialized suicide-prevention service for LGBTQ+ youth
description:
The Trump administration is ending funding for specialized suicide-prevention services for LGBTQ+ youth. The option on the 988 suicide and crisis lifeline is being eliminated on July 17.

When someone contacts 988, they can press 3 if they identify as LGBTQ+ youth. That connects the person to specialized counseling services tailored for such youth, who’re at a higher risk of suicide than their peers.

Mark Henson is with The Trevor Project, one of several organizations contracted to provide those services: "In less than a month, the program that has bipartisan backing and has had 1.3 million LGBTQ+ young people use ... It would no longer be available for those who need it most."

He says, more recently, nearly 60,000 individuals have used the service every month.

------------------------------------------------------

title: Trump says U.S. 'totally obliterated' nuclear facilities in Iran
description:
The U.S. military has joined with Israel to launch military strikes against Iran, a dramatic escalation in the years-long effort by both nations to prevent Tehran from acquiring a nuclear weapon.

"We have completed our very successful attack on the three Nuclear sites in Iran, including Fordow, Natanz, and Esfahan," President Trump wrote on Truth Social on Saturday.

Late Saturday evening, President Trump addressed the nation from the White House, joined by Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth. He confirmed the U.S. had launched “massive precision strikes” against three nuclear facilities within Iran. He originally announced the strikes in a post on Truth Social earlier Saturday evening.

“Our objective was the destruction of Iran’s nuclear enrichment capacity and a stop to the nuclear threat,” Trump said. “Tonight I can report to the world that the strikes were spectacular military success. Iran’s key nuclear enrichment facilities have been completely and totally obliterated.”

U.S. involvement comes amid an escalating conflict after Israel launched its own airstrikes against Iran a little over a week ago. The U.S. had moved additional military equipment and ships into the region in recent days. On Thursday, the president said he would decide “within two weeks” whether to strike Iran and clarified further on Friday that two weeks was the “maximum” he needed to make that call. Trump has also had multiple meetings with military and national security officials in the Situation Room as he weighed what move – if any – the U.S. should take.

------------------------------------------------------

title: Zoo Miami says Goliath the tortoise could be the oldest first-time father
description:
Goliath, the 135-year-old tortoise at a zoo in Miami, had a big celebration last weekend as he marked his first Father's Day.

Goliath’s hatchling was born in early June after incubating for about four months. It is the first Galápagos tortoise hatchling born at Zoo Miami. Goliath had been matched with several female tortoises to breed, but the process had been unsuccessful until he mated with Sweet Pea, the hatchling's mother.

The zoo has submitted applications to the Guinness World Records to consider Goliath for the title of "Oldest First-Time Father in History.”

title: Free American-Israeli hostage returns home
description:
A dual U.S.-Israeli citizen — the last surviving American hostage in Gaza — has returned to the United States.

Edan Alexander had been held by Hamas militants until his release in May. Crowds lined the streets in Tenafly, N.J., waving Israeli and U.S. flags and cheering as an SUV brought the 21-year-old back home.

Alexander was captured while on duty serving as an Israeli soldier during the Hamas-led attacks on southern Israel in October of 2023. He was released last month, in a standalone deal negotiated between President Trump’s administration and Hamas, who said it had been holding secret talks with the U.S. in the days leading up to his release.

Hamas said Alexander’s release was meant as part of “steps taken to establish a ceasefire” with Israel, but a ceasefire has still not come. Deadly Israeli bombardment of Gaza continues daily while 53 hostages remain in captivity there, more than half of whom are believed to be dead.

title: Mahasin al-Zaneen is a single mom in Gaza City, raising eight kids in a tent
description:
At least half a million people in Gaza are starving and the territory risks being plunged into famine, according to a UN-backed report issued by dozens of experts on hunger. NPR spent time with a starving single mother in Gaza City to document the family's struggles for survival.

Israel is severely restricting food supplies into Gaza and trying to control its distribution, saying it's to prevent Hamas from benefiting. International aid groups say it amounts to collective punishment. Gaza's Health Ministry says more than 400 people have been killed by Israeli fire trying to reach food aid since late March.

title: Sabrina Carpenter joins the 'song of the summer' race
description:
Sabrina Carpenter has joined the race to score this year’s “unofficial song” of the summer.

2024 gave pop fans a crowded race for the year’s unofficial song of the summer, as major stars and new faces flooded the market with massive pop hits. This year's been slower, as the pop charts have been loaded with last year’s hits alongside new ones from the country star Morgan Wallen and the ever-present hit “Ordinary,” by the singer Alex Warren.

This week, the song-of-the-summer sweepstakes finally gets a rowdy pop contender: Sabrina Carpenter’s “Manchild,” which debuted on this week’s "Billboard" Hot 100 at No. 1.

title: Israel's president seeks support in destroying Iran nuclear sites
description:
In an interview with NPR, Israeli president Isaac Herzog is calling for international support in destroying Iran’s main nuclear facilities. President Trump says he has not made a decision whether to take part in attacking Iran. NPR’s Daniel Estrin spoke with Herzog in Jerusalem.

Herzog told NPR that any decision about U.S. military strikes on Iran should be made by President Trump and his team. He also said Israel decided to attack days ago after sharing intelligence with the U.S. about Iran’s nuclear plans. The U.S. National Intelligence Director testified in March that U.S. intelligence officials did not think Iran was building a nuclear weapon. Trump has dismissed the assessment.

title: NYC comptroller arrested outside immigration court
description:
New York City Comptroller and mayoral candidate Brad Lander was arrested yesterday outside an immigration court as immigration officers were trying to take a migrant into custody.

Video shows Lander being led away in handcuffs by two men who appear to be masked law enforcement officials, typical of recent practices of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Lander said he was escorting a migrant from court and asked to see the person’s arrest warrant.

"They would not show me the warrant," Lander said, "and I said I would let go of his arm as soon as they showed it to me and you saw what happened."
A spokesperson for the Department of Homeland Security said Lander was arrested for assaulting law enforcement and impeding a federal court officer.

title: What playing Minecraft tells researchers about social learning
description: Minecraft is helping science! Researchers are using it to study how people learn.⁠

title: At least 15 dead in Russia's latest strikes on Ukraine
description:
Russia's latest attack on Ukraine is again one of its largest, lasting more nine hours and killing at least 15 civilians and injuring nearly 100 others in Kyiv.⁠
⁠
Ukrainian Air Defense units spent hours trying to shoot down drones and missiles. At least a dozen sites were hit — many of them residential buildings. Videos posted by Ukrainian authorities showed the collapse of part of an apartment complex. Emergency crews are working to pull survivors from the rubble.⁠
⁠
The strikes come as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is attending the G7 summit in Canada, pushing for stronger sanctions on Russia.⁠

title: Palestinians killed trying to reach food aid sites as Israel's blockade causes widespread hunger
description: Palestinians have been killed almost daily trying to reach food distribution sites built in Israeli military red zones. NPR’s Anas Baba was at Gaza City’s Al-Shifa Hospital where he documented the aftermath of Israeli tank fire and shelling on what witnesses say were crowds of desperately hungry people.

title: Spaniards turn water pistols on visitors to protest mass tourism
description:
Protesters in Spain have again expressed anger at overtourism as hundreds turned out to march against mass tourism in southern Spain. On Sunday, activists used water pistols to splash unsuspecting tourists in Barcelona and on the Spanish island of Mallorca.

Some Spaniards say that their rent prices are rising, because more apartments in their cities are being set aside for tourists.

Correction: A previous version of this post had an incorrect date.

title: Antarctic emperor penguin decline could be worse than expected
description:
Researchers say that the number of emperor penguins in Antarctica may be declining faster than feared.

Writing in the journal "Nature," researchers say they tracked the penguins using satellite data between 2009 and 2024, seeing declines of more than 20%.

title: Sen. Padilla forcibly removed from DHS press conference
description:
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem is blaming California Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla for interrupting her news conference yesterday. She and Padilla were in the same federal building in Los Angeles. She was talking about federal immigration raids in LA.

Padilla says he moved toward Noem to ask a question when he was forcibly removed from the room by federal agents, forced to the ground and then handcuffed. But Secretary Noem says Padilla lunged toward her. She says he never identified himself, although several recordings of the incident show Padilla identifying himself in the room before he is taken away.

title: Air India flight crashes with more than 240 aboard
description:
An Air India flight with 242 passengers and 12 crew aboard crashed shortly after departure in India's northwestern city of Ahmedabad today. It’s not yet clear how many people have been killed or injured.

The chairman of the group that operates Air India said in a statement that flight AI171, which was bound for London's Gatwick Airport, was involved in a “tragic incident.”

It’s the first ever crash of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft, according to the Aviation Safety Network database.

Reuters says the aircraft gave a "Mayday" call, signaling an emergency before it crashed. Local media say the jet crashed into a building that houses medical doctors.

title: Riots continue for second night in Northern Ireland
description:
There’s been a second night of riots in parts of Northern Ireland.

It began Monday, after two Romanian-speaking teens were arraigned in court for an alleged sexual assault. Angry neighbors then began hunting for other eastern europeans or foreign-born people to attack. Hundreds of masked rioters have thrown molotov cocktails, smashed windows and set fire to cars. Police have deployed water cannons in response.

Authorities say five people have been arrested and more than 30 police officers have been injured.

Residents have been posting flags and signs on their doors with their nationalities — to try to discourage rioters from targeting them.

title: Dave Portnoy backed Trump for president in 2024. NPR asked if his expectations have been met so far
description: Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy backed Donald Trump for president in 2024. NPR Morning Edition host Steve Inskeep asked him if he has met his expectations so far. “He has in my mind done what he said he was going to do,” Portnoy said. “Now I had a rant about tariffs because I’m in the stock market and I lost a lot of money. So I’m going to rant about that. He had a quote later that it wasn’t his stock market. It was Biden’s. Well that’s garbage, it’s yours.”

title: Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy in conversation with NPR's Steve Inskeep
description: Barstool Sports caters to a large male audience. Its founder, Dave Portnoy, defines ‘bro culture’ “as somebody who maybe likes sports and wants to get laid.” He told NPR Morning Edition host Steve Inskeep, “We consider ourselves a comedy brand and would come under fire for things. So on our end, it was on schools. It was in the media. And really, I felt that that was something that drove me to probably be a little bit more political.”

title: Copenhagen dealt with a costly flood in 2011. This is the city's plan to become floodproof
description: In July of 2011, more than 5 inches of rain fell on Copenhagen in the matter of hours, flooding the Danish capital and filling its streets with raw sewage. Now the city has created a 1.3 billion-dollar investment to try and make Copenhagen floodproof.

title: Ed, a runaway zebra, captured in Tennessee
description:
Officials in central Tennessee have finally caught a runaway pet zebra.
Ed the zebra was picked up in a pasture in central Tennessee. Authorities literally picked him up — Tennessee officials wrapped up the zebra in a net and a helicopter team airlifted him to a waiting animal trailer.

Ed escaped from his owner last month — he arrived in the Christiana community in central Tennessee, on May 30, and his owner reported him missing the next day. He gained fame by running in and out of Interstate 24 traffic. No injuries were reported.

The pursuit came one month after a runway kangaroo shut down a section of Alabama interstate.

title: Israeli forces detain protestors as they seize Gaza-bound boat
description:
Israeli forces seized a small ship carrying aid headed for Gaza over the weekend, detaining a prominent climate change activist and other protestors in the process.

The British-flagged ship, the Madleen, set sail from Italy a week ago to protest Israel's blockade of Gaza and deliver a symbolic amount of aid. Early Monday, Israeli forces said they took command of the vessel at sea, detaining Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg and the rest of the crew. Israel said it would return those detained to their home countries.

Drones off the coast of Malta attacked an aid a ship sent by the same group in May, damaging the vessel. No one claimed responsibility but the group blamed Israel.

Israel has banned all international aid from reaching Gaza for two months and recently implemented its own system of limited deliveries under armed guard.

In an exclusive interview, Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy tells NPR’s Morning Edition why President Trump has met his expectations, what he wishes the President would do differently and what Democrats need to do to win back the votes of men like him.

title: Lizards are evolving at hyper speed in Puerto Rican cities
description:
Lizards are evolving at hyper speed in Puerto Rican cities. These turbocharged genetic adaptations mean they can run and move faster than their countryside cousins. But why? Evolutionary biologists Shane Campbell-Staton and Kristin Winchell are studying how the urban environment is spurring rapid genetic adaptations in this lizard species.

This video includes footage from an episode of the PBS docuseries HumanFootprintPBS: “The Urban Jungle”, Season 1. @shane.campbellstaton is also hosting an upcoming second season of the docuseries, which is produced by @daysedge productions.

title: Marco Rubio said no one has died due to USAID cuts. This mom disagrees
description:
In testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee in May, Secretary of State Marco Rubio declared that no one has died because of cuts to USAID  — the cutoff of billions of dollars of U.S. support for global health programs.

One mother from Nigeria begs to differ.

Mariam Mohammed, a widowed mother of two, says her younger son — 7-year-old Babagana Bukar Mohammed — died as a result of the disruptions to U.S. foreign aid.

title: D-Day anniversary observed in Normandy
description:
Today is the 81st anniversary of D-Day, the start of the Allied operation in 1944 to land troops on the French shore of Normandy and the final assault on Nazi Germany. The operation had been kept secret until hundreds of thousands of Allied troops stormed the shore.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth commemorated the anniversary with veterans at the American Cemetery overlooking the shore in the village of Colleville-sur-Mer.

title: New Zealand's Parliament suspends Māori lawmakers over protest
description:
New Zealand legislators voted Thursday to enact suspensions from Parliament for three lawmakers who performed a Māori haka to protest a proposed law.

Hana-Rāwhiti Maipi-Clarke received a seven-day ban and the leaders of her political party, Debbie Ngarewa-Packer and Rawiri Waititi, were barred for 21 days. Three days had been the longest ban for a lawmaker from New Zealand's Parliament.

The lawmakers from Te Pāti Māori, the Māori Party, performed the haka, a chanting dance of challenge, last November to oppose a widely unpopular bill, now defeated, that they said would reverse Indigenous rights.

The protest drew global headlines and provoked months of debate among lawmakers about what the consequences for the lawmakers' actions should be and whether New Zealand's Parliament welcomed or valued Māori culture — or felt threatened by it.

title: Queen Elizabeth's advice to Jacinda Ardern about multitasking motherhood and leadership
description:
Jacinda Ardern, former prime minister of New Zealand, was the second person to give birth while holding elected office. So, who did she turn to for advice? Queen Elizabeth.

“She just completely straight-faced said, ‘Well, you just get on with it,’” Ardern told All Things Considered host Mary Louise Kelly.

title: Collection of personal data on food stamps recipients on hold
description:
The U.S. Department Of Agriculture says it’s suspending a demand for personal data about people who get federal food assistance.

Last month, the USDA told states they’d be required to turn over names, birth dates, Social Security numbers and addresses of everyone who applied for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, known as SNAP, over the last five years. The guidance cited a presidential executive order that calls for data-sharing to find fraud, waste and abuse and came as the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, has been amassing data for purposes that include immigration enforcement.

A coalition sued the USDA in federal court, saying the data demand did not comply with federal privacy laws.

In a recent court filing, a USDA official said the agency has not yet collected SNAP data and will not until all necessary legal requirements are met.

title: White House revokes policy ensuring emergency access to abortions
description:
The Trump administration announced on Tuesday that it plans to revoke guidance directing hospitals to provide emergency abortions to women whose lives are in danger. That also included states where abortion is outlawed.

But there’s a federal law that’s still on the books requiring hospitals to provide emergency reproductive care, so it’s not clear if the Trump administration is instructing hospitals to turn away women in medical emergencies.

title: Details on Ukraine's bold 'Trojan trucks' attack surface
description:
There’s still a lot of astonishment over Ukraine’s drone attacks across Russia on Sunday. The drones hit several Russian airbases, spread deep across the Russian heartland. Some bases were more than 2,500 miles from Ukraine or above the Arctic Circle. Ukraine says the attacks were part of "Operation Spider’s Web."

On Tuesday, days after its strikes on Russian airbases, Ukraine says it hit a strategic bridge in the occupied region of Crimea. Ukraine says it used underwater explosives to rupture the Kerch Strait Bridge, which Russia uses to move military supplies to its troops fighting in Ukraine.

title: DHS raises its arrest quotas for ICE officers to 3,000 per day
description:
The Department of Homeland Security is increasing its arrest quotas for immigration officers — at the same it is running out of money and space to hold detainees.

DHS Secretary Kristi Noem confirmed over the weekend that Immigration and Customs Enforcement is now required to conduct 3,000 arrests a day, an increase from 1,800.

But the department is also struggling to keep up with its own pace — it currently has more people in detention than it has detention beds. The Trump administration is asking congress for billions of dollars to hire more people and increase detention space, but that money may not come for several more weeks.

The new arrest quotas also come amid efforts to streamline and expedite deportations, but with limited resources, including personnel, to carry out those efforts.

title: There's one particular X account that Elon Musk interacts with a lot⁠
description:
From last August to this April, Elon Musk interacted with one particular X account on a near-daily basis: Mario Nawfal’s.⁠
⁠
The Australian crypto entrepreneur mostly posts about current affairs, including false claims and unverified information. Stories from Nawfal’s account have catapulted into President Trump’s feed via Musk – who, despite a step back from his official goverment role, had a big influence on the Trump administration.⁠
⁠
Nawfal told NPR that he doesn’t write his own posts, his team does. And, he says, they don’t vet the claims they post.⁠
⁠
“How the hell can I know? It’s impossible to know,” Nawfal said. “Even if I had a reporter on the ground, they probably wouldn't be able to find out the truth.”⁠

title: Jacinda Ardern thinks politics needs more kindess | NPR
description:
In 2017, Jacinda Ardern, the former Prime Minister of New Zealand, was sitting in her bathroom, anxiously anticipating the news of two potentially life-changing events.

One, the election results that could make her the youngest female head of government in the world. And the other, a pregnancy test that could not only make her a first-time mother, but determine how she might spend the first few months of her tenure as the leader of New Zealand.

As you may know now, Arden both won the election and gave birth later that year. Her term as prime minister included her wading through motherhood in the public eye and guiding the island nation through a devastating mass shooting. After several years in office as the 40th prime minister of New Zealand, Ardern stepped down, saying she "no longer had enough in the tank" to continue fulfilling the role.

Ardern reflects on these moments and more in her new memoir, A Different Kind of Power. She joined All Things Considered Host Mary Louise Kelly to discuss that pivotal time and the lessons she took from her time in politics.

Host: Mary Louise Kelly

title: 8 people set on fire in attack in Boulder, Colo.
description:
The FBI is investigating an attack in Boulder, Colo., as terrorism after eight people were set on fire at an outdoor mall yesterday.

Local FBI officials identified the male suspect as 45-year-old Mohamed Sabry Soliman. They say he used a makeshift flamethrower and threw it at a crowd. Officials say the suspect yelled “Free Palestine” during a march in support of releasing Israeli hostages held by Hamas. They believe he acted alone.

title: I told my co-worker her scented candle makes me sick, but she still lights it! What do I do? ⁠
description:
I told my co-worker her scented candle makes me feel sick, but she still lights it! What do I do now? ⁠

⁠What's your pov on the etiquette of shared spaces? Have you been in a similar situation?⁠
⁠
Celeste Headlee, journalist and author of “We Need to Talk: How to Have Conversations That Matter,” responds to this anonymous audience question.⁠
⁠
"Dear Life Kit" is NPR Life Kit’s advice column. To hear Headlee answer more audience questions, search “Life Kit” wherever you listen to podcasts.⁠
⁠

title: Global health experts draw attention to deadly snake bite problem
description:
Experts gathered at the World Health Assembly in Geneva this month to talk about a problem that’s often hidden: The roughly 140,000 people who die every year from snake bites.

Venomous snake bites aren’t often at the top of the global health agenda, but each year, millions of people get bitten — often far away from antivenom treatment. To raise awareness, a new initiative called Strike Out Snakebite (SOS) scattered human-sized snake statues throughout Geneva.

Going forward, David Lalloo, the vice chancellor of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, says the initiative aims to boost funding for antivenom research and help bolster health systems so they can get bitten people to treatment before it’s too late.
